Title: Prove the sequence of solutions of $1^{x}+2^{x}+...+n^{x}=n^2$ is convergent and monotone
Content: For every $n\ge 4$ let $x_n$ be the unique solution of $1^{x_n}+2^{x_n}+...+n^{x_n}=n^2$ $(i)$ Prove that $x_n$ is convergent and find the limit. $(ii)$ Prove { $x_n$ } is monotone for $n\ge 4$ For $(i)$ , we have $\lim\limits_{n\rightarrow \infty}\frac{1^{x_n}+2^{x_n}+\ldots+n^{x_n}}{n^2}=1$ $\Rightarrow$ $\lim\limits_{n\rightarrow \infty}\frac{(n+1)^{x_n}}{2n+1}=1$ (via S.C theorem) With some calculations we get $\lim\limits_{n\rightarrow \infty}x_n=\lim\limits_{n\rightarrow \infty}\left(1+\frac{\ln(2)}{\ln(n+1)}\right)$ , so $x_n$ is convergent and $$\lim\limits_{n\rightarrow \infty}x_n=1$$ I need help with $(ii)$ .
AcceptedAnswer: (i) For $n \geq 2$ , the function $x \mapsto \sum_{k=1}^{n} k^x $ is strictly increasing and hence $x_n > 1$ . Then by the Jensen's inequality, $$ n = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{k=1}^{n} k^{x_n} \geq \biggl( \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} k \biggr)^{x_n} = \biggl( \frac{n+1}{2} \biggr)^{x_n} $$ and hence $$ x_n \leq \frac{\log n}{\log((n+1)/2)}. $$ This proves that $x_n \to 1$ by the squeezing lemma. (ii) Consider the functions $f(t) = t^{x_n}$ and $g(t) = 2t - 1$ . We observe that $f(t)$ is strictly convex on $[0, \infty)$ , $f(1) = g(1) = 1$ , and $\sum_{k=1}^{n} f(k) = \sum_{k=1}^{n} g(k)$ . Since $f$ is strictly convex and intersects with the line $g$ at $t = 1$ , one of the following two scenarios must arise: Scenario 1 : $f(t) > g(t)$ for all $t > 1$ , or Scenario 2 : There exists $t_* \geq 1$ with $f(t_*) = g(t_*)$ such that $f(t) < g(t)$ for $t \in (1, t_*)$ and $f(t) > g(t)$ for $t > t_*$ . However, Item 3 leaves the second scenario as the only possible case with $t_* \leq n$ . Hence, it follows that $f(n+1) > g(n+1)$ and we have $$ \sum_{k=1}^{n+1} k^{x_n} > \sum_{k=1}^{n} (2k-1) = (n+1)^2. $$ From this, we conclude that $x_n > x_{n+1}$ .
